objdescid.origination: William Blakeinventor, delineator, printer, Colorist? The authorship of the hand coloring has been questioned by David Bindman, Andrew Wilton and others. It might have been added by someone other than Blake. See the comments in Butlin 296.

objinfo.printdate: 1795The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression was printed in 1795. This is the only extant impression from that printing session.
objinfo.medium: color printed relief etching(?) with water color and pen and ink additions to the impressionThe printing matrix would appear to be a copperplate etched in relief. Evidence for this is provided by indentations around some of the printed areas representing God in this impression in the Philadelphia Museum of Art and by letters blind-embossed lower right, probably created by a platemaker's mark, visible in the impression in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York (Butlin 295).

objnote.p: "God Judging Adam," loosely based on Genesis 3:17-19, embodies Blake's criticism of legalistic tyranny, judgment, and punishment of the sort he also explores through the character of Urizen in the illuminated books of the mid-1790s. God, riding on a fiery chariot, holds his book of laws on his lap and points toward Adam with his extended right arm. Adam's long beard indicates that he has already been marked by mortality.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God, who is old, gowned, and bearded and has long hair, sits on a flaming chariot drawn by two horses. At least the frontmost horse has a flame-like mane and tail. God extends his right arm, hand, and index finger to point in judgment at the nude and hunched or bowing form of Adam, who stands before him with eyes down and face partly obscured by his long, flowing beard. God’s left hand rests on a book or tablet (of laws?) on his lap. God may be holding the frontmost horse's rein in his right hand or possibly a rod or scepter pointing at Adam. Beams of light radiate from the flaming disc or globe behind God. Grass, moss, lichens, or some such vegetation may be growing beneath the feet of Adam and the horses.

component.illusobjdesc: God sits on a chariot of flame. He is bearded, gowned, and old, and has long hair. Flames surround him as he faces to the left with his head bent slightly forward and down to look at Adam. His expression and posture may suggest anger. His right arm, hand, and index finger are extended to point at Adam, who stands before him; God may also be using his right hand to hold the frontmost horse's rein or a rod or scepter. His left arm is bent at the elbow, and his left hand rests on the book or tablet on his lap. His bare left foot is visible beneath the hem of his gown, and appears to be resting on a platform of the chariot.
A book or tablet (of laws?) rests on God’s lap.
God may be holding a scepter or rod in his right hand, pointed toward Adam. Alternatively, this line could simply be one of the reins extending from the frontmost horse.

God sits on a chariot that seems to be made mostly of fire. Flames rise upward behind him, sideways beneath his body, and downwards below his foot. The circle or globe behind God is filled with flames; it may be the sun. God’s foot rests on a plinth-like platform of the chariot.

Two horses, facing left, pull the chariot upon which God sits. The frontmost horse strides to the left with its back right hoof raised. The legs of the horse behind it are not pictured. At least the frontmost horse has a flame-like mane and tail and is wearing a harness. One rein extends to the right towards God.

Adam, nude, muscular, and old, stands before God with his shoulders hunched over in a bow, his head bent forward, and his eyes down. This posture suggests reverence and perhaps fear. He has long hair, with a prominent forelock, and his beard obscures the lower part of his face. He faces to the right with his left leg bent behind him, and his left foot poised on tiptoe. He may be striding toward God. His arms (or at least his right arm) are probably bent upward, for his right hand is raised to his forehead and his palms may be together in prayer or supplication.
Beams of light or radiance extend from the disc or globe behind God’s chariot and fill the sky.
The hues and reticulations of the color printing suggest that grass, moss, lichens, or some such vegetation grows beneath the feet of Adam and the horses.
